official-title.#text:
Calling for further defense against the People’s Republic of China’s state-sponsored cyber-enabled
			 theft of trade secrets, including by the People’s Liberation Army.

committee-name.#tail:
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to aggressively implement and coordinate the Strategy on Mitigating the
			 Theft of United States Trade Secrets;

to continue to advance investigations into cyber espionage by
			 actors originating in the PRC;

text.#text:
calls on the United States Government to continue to condemn cyber-enabled espionage for the
			 purposes of stealing intellectual property and trade secrets, pursue
			 counter intelligence capacities, and prosecute such individuals should
			 they enter United States territory;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to estimate the loss from cyber theft, compile a
			 list of actors that cause the most damage to United States firms by
			 intellectual property rights theft and pursue a dispute settlement case at
			 the World Trade Organization;

to update the
			 unclassified report to
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Office of the National Counterintelligence Executive
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Office of the National Counterintelligence Executive

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on Foreign Economic Collection and
			 Industrial Espionage in 2009–2011 with information that includes the cyber
			 threat from the People’s Republic of China against United States companies
			 and critical infrastructure;

to restrict military-to-military contacts with the PLA in
			 compliance with United States laws, including the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
National Defense
			 Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

to expand
			 warnings to United States companies about the broad scope of tools to
			 illicit trade secrets used by actors originating in the PRC, including
			 cyber theft, physical trespass of the factories or other facilities of
			 United States firms, intrusion of computers, and use of Universal Serial
			 Bus (USB) drives, money, travel, gifts, promises of employment, and social
			 media;
and the

to provide briefings of the United
			 States-China cyber-security working group meetings in 2013; and

text.#text:
calls on Federal departments and agencies to expand cooperation with allies and partners to better
			 coordinate defense against cyber threats.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
as the world’s most active and
			 persistent perpetrator of economic espionage;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
United States Office of the
			 National Counterintelligence Executive
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Office of the National Counterintelligence Executive

text.#text: Whereas the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has been labeled by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
investigated
			 the PRC’s major telecommunications companies and concluded in a bipartisan
			 report released October 2012 that Chinese businesses Huawei Technologies’
			 and ZTE Incorporated’s provision of equipment to United States critical
			 infrastructure could undermine core United States national security
			 interests;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
issued the Administration’s Strategy on Mitigating the
			 Theft of United States Trade Secrets and stated,

quote.#text:
We cannot look back years from now and wonder why we did nothing in the face of real threats to our
			 security and economy.

text.#text:
Whereas Mandiant warned that APT1 is only one of more than 20 Advanced Persistent Threat groups
			 originating in the PRC;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: James Clapper reported to
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in March 2013 that the
			 PRC remains one of the most capable and persistent intelligence threats;
reported to
in a report entitled

quote.#text: Military and Security Developments Involving the People’s Republic of China

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
asserted that these intrusions carried out by the PRC were focused
			 on exfiltrating information through computer network exploitation (CNE)
			 capabilities to support state-sponsored intelligence collection of United
			 States national defense programs;
James Clapper reported to
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of the Director of National Intelligence

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in January 2014 that
			 China seeks to revise the multi-stakeholder model of Internet governance
			 while continuing its expansive worldwide program of network exploitation
			 and intellectual property theft;

text.#text: Whereas these five hackers were identified as part of Unit 61398 of the PLA;

Whereas the indictment detailed the threat from Unit 61398 of the PLA based in Shanghai in the PRC;
			 and

Whereas this indictment was the first time charges were brought against state actors for cyber
			 infiltration of United States commercial entities: Now, therefore, be it;

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 643 IH: Calling for further defense against the People’s Republic of China’s state-sponsored cyber-enabled theft of trade secrets, including by the People’s Liberation Army.
